content.description: Sit-start with hands on ridge, low left foot, high right heel. Mantle up and over somehow and then use crack and good holds to top out.
content.location: Just left of the big ground boulder that the traverse starts on top of - see photo

content.description: Stand-start with double undercling and feet as low as possible on slopy slightly positive rock just above the ground. Control the start (this is the crux), then quickly hit one of the positive edges at head level to stabilize. Climb straight up on edges (avoid juggy ledges on either side) to top out.
content.location: A bit right of the triangular cave. Look up between the two juggiest topout areas and then look down for the slopy protrusion at ground level.

content.description: Sit-start on two side pulls and low feet. Pull up to nice edge and then move up and left to even nicer edge/shelf and then top out
content.location: Strip boulder, just right of the triangular cave

content.description: Long traverse to three possible top-outs, each progressively harder.
content.location: Stand-start on ground-boulder above and right of the horizontal crack. Match the blocky hold and use rough slopy hands to set your feet. Get a left foot in the crack just under the lip (bit of a blind move) and start using the upper crack as undercling holds. After a few moves shift down and use the crack holds as crimps. Three possible topouts:Triangular shelf: V2Rough leaf: V3/4All the way through to big blocks: V4/5

content.description: Slightly overhanging with lots of sharp juggy holds. This is one of the wettest sections of the whole area, so be sure to inspect the rock before starting.Sit start matching the deep flake with bad feet. Go straight up to the horn and then top out to the left.
content.location: Just right of Hercules right behind the Coffin on the Strip boulder.

content.description: What feels like a classic Pawtuckaway mantle problem on skin friendly rock! Squat start with hands on the good rail as for "Groop Prooject". Campus up a left heel and bump out right to a good crimp. From here bump the RH up again to a slopey edge, then somehow rock over that bomb heel and grab the lip. Warm up that left hammy!
content.location: When facing the Coffin prow continue to the right of the boulder and uphill for about 30 seconds. Same start as "Groop Prooject"
Just behind the Coffin on the Strip Boulder. Look for the chalk and brushed areas to find those starting hands

content.description: Stand start on a wide sloping hold at the lip, then traverse right into the crack to top out. Stay above the lip on the good rock and avoid stepping underneath as these holds are crumbly (and the low feet reduce the difficulty & quality of movement). Use high heel hooks instead.
content.location: To the left of The Coffin along the fairly short, chossy ridge of rock. Before you get to the Cat Pine Dyno. Look for an obvious crack.

content.description: Jugs at the beginning, crimps and slopers at the end. This one is much easier in cold weather but watch the shoes and finger skin because the holds are sharp.
content.location: This is the last problem on the left side of the Strip, and Cat Pine is just to the left of it.Either sit-start directly below the lip or start out right on the sharp triangular hold and traverse for a move or two to the left. From the jugs in the middle go up right to one of two small crimps, get a high left foot on the blocky knob, and then go up left to the bad sloper. Get your right up there too and then mantle to top out.

content.description: Think small thoughts and squeeze into the cave to sit start on a variety of rails and a large step for feet. Pull on and climb out of the cave until you can grab the sidepull crack. Crank up a heel and rock over onto the slab. There is no way to protect this without dabbing and trying to avoid dabbing is certainly part of the crux. Should produce a few laughs. The movement is surprisingly good.
content.location: In the small cave directly to the right of "The Waldo's"

content.description: The large, "long" boulder.  (More to be added)
